links.desc: This app is an employee directory and shows the final result of the 'Navigation Tutorial'.

entities.name: Navigation and Routing
entities.description: This tutorial illustrates the major features of navigation and routing inside SAPUI5 apps.
samplesAsSteps: Add a Back Button to the Not Found Page
Display a Target Without Changing the Hash
Navigate to Routes with Hard-Coded Patterns
Navigate to Routes with Mandatory Parameters
Allow Bookmarkable Tabs with Optional Query Parameters
Handle Invalid Hashes by Listening to Bypassed Events
Listen to Matched Events of Any Route

entities.name: Troubleshooting
entities.description: In this tutorial, we will show you some tools that will help you when you run into problems with your SAPUI5 app.

entities.name: Data Binding
entities.description: In this tutorial, we will explain the concepts of data binding in SAPUI5.
samplesAsSteps: Binding Paths: Accessing Properties in Hierarchically Structured Models
Aggregation Binding Using a Factory Function

entities.name: OData V2 Mock Server
entities.description: In this tutorial, we will explore some advanced features of the OData V2 mock server.
samplesAsSteps: Creating a Mock Server to Simulate Data

entities.name: OData V4
entities.description: In this tutorial, we will show you how to build a simple application using an OData V4 service.
samplesAsSteps: Add table with :n navigation to detail area

samples.name: OData V2 Dates - Use sap.ui.model.odata.type.DateTime for Edm.DateTime
samples.description: This sample explains how to use the OData V2 Edm.DateTime type in SAPUI5 applications.

samples.name: OData V2 Timestamps - Use sap.ui.model.odata.type.DateTimeOffset for Edm.DateTimeOffset
samples.description: This sample explains how to use the OData V2 Edm.DateTimeOffset type in SAPUI5 applications.

samples.name: OData V2 Times - Use sap.ui.model.odata.type.Time for Edm.Time
samples.description: This sample explains how to use the OData V2 Edm.Time type in SAPUI5 applications.

samples.name: OData V4 Dates - Use sap.ui.model.odata.type.Date for Edm.Date
samples.description: This sample explains how to use the OData V4 Edm.Date type in SAPUI5 applications.

samples.name: OData V4 Timestamps - Use sap.ui.model.odata.type.DateTimeOffset for Edm.DateTimeOffset
samples.description: This sample explains how to use the OData V4 Edm.DateTimeOffset type in SAPUI5 applications.

samples.name: OData V4 Times - Use sap.ui.model.odata.type.TimeOfDay for Edm.TimeOfDay
samples.description: This sample explains how to use the OData V4 Edm.TimeOfDay type in SAPUI5 applications.

samples.name: Date Type - Source As Date
samples.description: This sample explains the formatting options of the Date type with the date being available as date object.

samples.name: Date Type - Source As String
samples.description: This sample explains the formatting options of the Date type with the date being available as string.

samples.name: DateTime Type
samples.description: This sample explains the formatting options of the DateTime type.

samples.name: Time Type
samples.description: This sample explains the formatting options of the Time type.

samples.name: FileSize Type
samples.description: This sample explains the formatting options of the FileSize type.

samples.name: Busy Indicator
samples.description: A busy indicator can be used to block the entire screen until an operation has finished.

samples.name: Control Busy Indicator
samples.description: A control's busy indicator can be used to block parts of the screen until an operation has finished. In this example we block the content of only one out of two panels.

samples.name: Field Groups
samples.description: A control's field group id can be used to define a virtual group of fields that should be validated together. Field groups can be validated usinf the ValidateFieldGroup event if the user presses the enter key in a field belonging to the field group or focusses a control outside of the field group.

samples.name: HTML
samples.description: With the HTML controls you can easily embed any kind of HTML content into your UI5 mobile application.

samples.name: Static HTML Provided as a String
samples.description: This is the simple use case for the HTML control: Some - usually decorative - HTML fragment is specified as a string and set to the content property. Without further configuration, the HTML control will convert this string to DOM nodes whenever it has to render.

samples.name: Static HTML Provided With Preserved DOM
samples.description: The second use case is similar to the first one: The HTML fragment is specified as a string. The difference is that after the first rendering, the HTML control tries to preserve the created DOM nodes as long as possible. Before each re-rendering step, the existing DOM is preserved in some hidden page area, and then the control and its relatives (parents, siblings) are rendered - this creates a new DOM node hierarchy. After the rendering, the preserved DOM content of the controls is integrated in the newly created DOM tree.

samples.name: Icon
samples.description: Built with an embedded font, icons scale well, and can be altered with CSS. They can also fire a press event. See the Icon Explorer for more icons.

samples.name: Integer Format
samples.description: Formats and parses only the integer digits. The decimal digits are ignored.

samples.name: Float Format
samples.description: Formats and parses both integer and decimal digits.

samples.name: Currency Format
samples.description: Formats the number by using the parameters defined for the given currency code. Either currency symbol, currency code or none of them can be included in the final formatted string. It parses the given string into an array which contains both the currency number and currency code.

samples.name: InvisibleMessage
samples.description: The InvisibleMessage provides a way to programmaticaly expose dynamic content changes in a way that can be announced by screen readers.

samples.name: InvisibleText
samples.description: Many controls provide the associations ariaLabelledBy and ariaDescribedBy for accessibility purposes. The InvisibleText control can be used by application to provide hidden texts on the UI which can be referenced via these associations.

samples.name: Async View loading and rendering
samples.description: Example for Views with async source loading and the impact on rendering.

samples.name: Preprocessor example with XMLView
samples.description: A small example for View Preprocessor usage with XMLViews.

samples.name: Typed View
samples.description: Based on defining views via Typed Views primarily, this small sample demonstrates basic routing configuration, event handler registration, asynchronous content creation incl. JS fragments and stable IDs. See the provided sample code.

samples.name: OData V2 Service Consumption
samples.description: Example for OData V2 service consumption with an OData V4 model

samples.name: Deep Create Handling
samples.description: Example on how to deal with deep creates in an OData V4 model

samples.name: Draft Handling and Data Synchronisation
samples.description: Example of an OData V4 model consuming a draft service that shows how to synchronise data between a list report and an object page

samples.name: Operation Binding
samples.description: OData V4 model operation bindings example; refer to the Sales Orders example to understand other OData V4 model features

samples.name: Sales Orders
samples.description: Example for OData V4 EPM Sales Orders

samples.name: Sales Orders Template
samples.description: Example for OData V4 EPM Sales Orders using XML Templating

samples.name: Sales Orders TP100
samples.description: Example for consuming an OData V4 Service

samples.name: Sales Orders TP100 via OData V2 Service
samples.description: Example for consuming an OData V2 Service via an OData V4 Model

samples.name: XMLComposite: basic example
samples.description: Basic example to show the structure of an XML composite control

samples.name: XMLComposite: example showing usage of aggregation
samples.description: Example showing how aggregations can be dealt with in an XML composite control

samples.name: XML Templating: demo scenario
samples.description: Complete demo scenario for XML Templating based on OData V4 annotations

samples.name: XML Templating: demo scenario extension
samples.description: Complete demo scenario for XML Templating based on OData V4 annotations incl. custom extensions

samples.name: XML Templating: minimal sample
samples.description: Minimal sample for XML Templating. BEWARE: This is meant to be a pure code sample. (To run it, you would need a proxy which is configured properly.)

samples.name: XML Templating: UI5 OData types
samples.description: XML Templating sample with UI5 core primitive OData types

samples.name: Separate Value List Loading
samples.description: Separate loading of value lists to reduce size of OData service metadata to be loaded

samples.name: Using Matchers
samples.description: Matchers are used in OPA tests to retrieve controls that have to match a condition, eg: Property matching a value

samples.name: Finding controls by id
samples.description: OPA finds a control by its id, triggers a tap and then finds multiple controls by their ids

samples.name: How to write nested actions
samples.description: If you have complex control structures you are able to add actions based on the result of previous actions.

samples.name: How to structure your OPA tests with Page Objects
samples.description: If you have multiple pages or UI areas that have several operations, you should place reuse functions in Page Objects to make your OPA tests maintainable. The example shows as well how to share and reuse functionality within and across page objects.

samples.name: Using Gherkin with QUnit
samples.description: How to combine Gherkin and QUnit to run behavior driven development tests

samples.name: Using Gherkin with OPA5
samples.description: How to combine Gherkin and OPA5 to run behavior driven development tests

samples.name: Using Gherkin with OPA5 Page Objects
samples.description: How to combine Gherkin and OPA5 page objects to run behavior driven development tests

samples.name: Using Gherkin to load and test a UIComponent
samples.description: How to use Gherkin and OPA5 to load a UIComponent and run behavior driven development tests on it

samples.name: Theme-independent CSS-classes
samples.description: Sample display of 'sapTheme'-prefixed CSS classes for theme-independent styling of custom HTML/Controls. The set displayed is to be used to style static HTML elements.

samples.name: Basic Theme Parameters
samples.description: Sample provides a link to the Theme Parameter Toolbox. There you can easily search, preview, and filter semantic theme parameters.

samples.name: Route Patterns
samples.description: Syntax for the Route pattern property.

samples.name: Targets without a Router
samples.description: If you do not need bookmarks, a router is too complicated you can use Targets to lazy load your views and navigate through your application.

samples.name: Routing between Fullscreen pages a simple sample
samples.description: A mini app with 2 pages. Both are bookmarkable.

samples.name: Routing in a split screen layout with the master detail pattern
samples.description: A mini app with 2 detail pages. Both are bookmarkable.

samples.name: Routing with nested components consuming data from a mocked OData V2 service
samples.description: An app that shows how nested components with enabled routing can be used. This app uses a mocked OData V2 service and shows the 'Products', 'Categories' and 'Suppliers' entity sets and the relationships between them.

samples.name: Binding Path Matcher
samples.description: The binding path matcher checks if a control has a binding with the exact same binding context and/or binding property path in OPA tests.

samples.name: I18N Text Matcher
samples.description: The I18N text matcher checks if a control property has the same value as a text of an I18N file in OPA tests.

samples.name: Label For Matcher
samples.description: The LabelFor matcher searches for given control associated with labelFor property in OPA tests.

samples.name: Descendant Matcher
samples.description: The descendant matcher checks if a control has a given descendant.

samples.name: Basic Messages
samples.description: Shows how to create messages on the frontend and display them afterwards. This can be used for form validation on the frontend.

samples.name: Basic OData Messages
samples.description: Uses the OData V2 mock server to simulate an OData response containing different types of server side messages (error, warning, info, success).

samples.name: OData Messages Component
samples.description: Shows how to handle OData responses containing server side messages in component based apps. Also illustrates how the sap-message header works.

samples.name: Starting a UIComponent
samples.description: Use this function if you would like to run OPA tests for a single UIComponent (a component which creates entries in the DOM tree)

samples.name: Starting an app in an iFrame
samples.description: Use this function if you would like to run your app isolated from the other tests and your app starts with a html file.

samples.name: Starting a UIComponent with URL parameters
samples.description: Passing URL parameters from configurations when using UIComponent

samples.name: Starting an app in an iFrame with passing URL parameters to the iFrame
samples.description: Passing URL parameters to an app in an iFrame from configuration

samples.name: Simulating user interactions on UI5 controls with OPA5
samples.description: There are built-in actions for OPA and you are also able to write custom actions if they do not fit the control you are using.

samples.name: Simulating a simple backend request with OPA5
samples.description: This example is complementary to the OPA get started section in the developer guide. It shows how to simulate a simple backend server request with OPA5 and Sinon.JS

samples.name: Running OPA tests with Support Assistant checks
samples.description: This sample demonstrates how to extend existing OPA test/journey by plugging calls to Support Assistant extension assertions, with different severity and check scope parameters

samples.name: Creating and using OPA5 test libraries
samples.description: This sample demonstrates how to create and use a simple OPA5 test library

samples.name: Retrieving controls located in the static area with OPA5
samples.description: This sample demonstrates how to locate static area controls with OPA5

samples.name: Testing busy controls with OPA5
samples.description: This sample demonstrates how to test busy controls with OPA5

samples.name: OPA5 autoWait parameters
samples.description: This sample demonstrates how to take advantage of OPA5 autoWait parameters

samples.name: Hyphenation API
samples.description: This sample demonstrates usage of the Hyphenation API

samples.name: Commands
samples.description: This example demonstrates how to define shortcuts using commands in your application
